comment: As the address starts with 10 it should lógicaly belong to class B not class A? Is there a specific reason you are belonging it to class B?
Thank you. waiting for new video also.
Please provide cryptography and network security videos for free it will be very useful for many students who are unable to take subscription in app
The videos are so helpful thanks alot, and please,try to make more videos quickly

The address does belong to Class A and accordingly the problem was solved. The 10 that you are talking about is that the binary form of the first octet should start from the bits 1,0 if it belongs to Class B. But in this problem, the IP Address is 10.200.240.4, where the first octet is 10, the binary form of 10 in an octet is 00001010, where the first bit starts with 0. So 10.200.240.4 is a Class A address.
The address is actually in dotted-decimal notation not in binary notation. You can visit his previous videos in this playlist for clarification.
